Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Example:
eri jü:
this house
‘this house’

Feature: Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Example:
imin do:-ni: mü:-nin aruxxun bičči antasi Imin.river-GEN water-3 clear be.PTCP sweet
‘The water of Imin river is clear and sweet.’ 
(Hu & Chaoke 1986:100)

Feature: Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Example:
eri ‘this’
tari ‘that'

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Example:
omolə:-sal [grandson-PL]
xolə:-sal [mountain-PL]

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Comment: There is a suffix used for indication of place or kinship of nouns, meaning ‘those who live somewhere’ and ‘someone’s family, someone and others’ respectively’.
Example:
imin-sə:n [Imin-ASSOC] ‘those who live in Imin’
ülʤi-sə:n [Ulij-ASSOC] ‘the Uljis'

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Example:
xonin-i: nanda-wa:-ni
sheep-GEN skin-ACC-3SG
‘sheep skin (ACC)’
sin-i: a:wun-si
2SG-GEN hat-2SG
‘your hat’
min-i: jaxa
1SG-GEN baggage
‘my baggage’
min-i: bitig
1SG-GEN book
‘my book’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Example:
imin do:-ni: mü:-nin aruxxun bičči antasi Imin.river-GEN water-3 clear be.PTCP sweet
‘The water of Imin river is clear and sweet.’ 
(Hu & Chaoke 1986:100)

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Example:
aja xonin-sal
good sheep-PL
‘good sheep’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Comment: There is a nominative, an accusative and an undefinite accusative case.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Detailed comment: There are thirteen cases: Nominative, Genitive, Accusative, Indefinite Accusative, Dative, Locative, Directive, Prolative, Ablative, Elative, Delative, Instrumental, Comitative

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Example:
sire-ni: oro:n-du-ni bitig bi-si-n
desk-GEN surface-DAT-3SG book be-PRS.PTCP-3SG
‘There is a book on the desk.’

Feature: Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Comment: these forms are called “participles”, but they can function as a predicate in the clause and take argument indexes

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Comment: these forms are called “participles”, but they can function as a predicate in the clause and take argument indexes

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Comment: these forms are called “participles”, but they can function as a predicate in the clause and take argument indexes

Feature: Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Example: imanda-ʤi- ‘to be snowing’

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
bi: uxxe-dü i:-ʤixe:-weje, batu min-ewe tan-sa:
1SG door-DAT enter-SUC-1SG Batu 1SG-ACC notice-PST
‘As soon as I entered the door, Batu noticed me.’

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Example:
sin-ii jinji-saa-wa-si saa-suu you-GEN talk-PAST-ACC-2S know-PAST.1S
‘I understood what you said.’

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Comment: There is a so-called ‘regressive’ suffix with the meaning ‘back’.
Example:
eme-rgi-
come-REGR-
‘to come back’

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Are there conjugation classes?
Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Example:
eme-xeen-
come-CAUS-
‘to make someone come’

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Example:
ta:-ma:si-
pull-RECIP-
‘to pull each other’

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Example:
bi: malsin bi-sü:
1SG stock.farmer be-PST.PTCP.1SG
‘I was a stock farmer.’
imin do:-ni: mü:-nin aruxxun bičči antasi Imin.river-GEN water-3 clear be.PTCP sweet
‘The water of Imin river is clear and sweet.’ 
(Hu & Chaoke 1986:100)

Feature: Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Detailed comment:
bi- ‘to be’: subjunctive
o:- ‘become’: possibility, permission or obligation.
Example:
ga-ʤigu: bi-se:
take-FUT.1SG be-PST
‘I might have taken.’
ebbesi-mi o:-dan
swim-COOR become-PRS ‘(It is) possible/permitted/expected to swim.’

Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Comment: The verb bi- ‘to be’ can be used to denote durative or imperfect aspect. The verb nee- ‘to lay, keep’, used as an auxiliary after a subordinative converb, adds a perfective or resultative meaning.
Example:
a:si-mi bi-se:
sleep-COOR be-PST
‘(He) was (still) sleeping.’
xori:-cci ne:-se:
arrest-SUB lay-PST
‘(They) have arrested (him).’ ommo-cci nee-süü
forget-SUB lay-PST.1SG
‘I have forgotten.’

Feature: Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Comment: The verb bi- ‘to be’ can be used to denote remote past.
Example:
üli-ce: bi-se:
go-PST be-PST
‘He has already gone.’

Feature: Is verb compounding a regular process?
Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Example: də:ŋxo munda- ‘to make a telephone call’ (lit. ‘to hit telephone’), daNga ta:n- ‘to smoke’ (lit. ‘to pull tobacco’)

Feature: Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Comment: it is most probably identical with the copula
Example:
sire-ni: oro:n-du-ni bitig bi-si-n
desk-GEN surface-DAT-3SG book be-PRS.PTCP-3SG
‘There is a book on the desk.’

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Example:
sire-ni: oro:n-du-ni bitig bi-si-n
desk-GEN surface-DAT-3SG book be-PRS.PTCP-3SG
‘There is a book on the desk.’

Feature: Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Example:
tari beje e-se: nini-re
that man NEG-PST go-PRS
‘He didn’t go’.

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Example:
bi: uxxe-dü i:-ʤixe:-weje, batu min-ewe tan-sa:
1SG door-DAT enter-SUC-1SG Batu 1SG-ACC notice-PST
‘As soon as I entered the door, Batu noticed me.’

Feature: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Example:
kino: isi-mi güŋken ʤo:nʤi-mi
movie see-PRS.PTCP.1S saying think-PRS.PTCP.1S
‘I think that I will watch a movie.’

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Example:
eri min-i: morin öntö
this 1SG-GEN horse NEG
‘This is not my horse.’
eri üxür-nin i:ge-je a:sin 
this ox-3 horn-INAC NEG
‘This ox has no horns.’

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Comment: if the pronominal subject can be omitted, clause-initial negation marking cannot be excluded
Detailed comment: “There is a negative adverb unege ‘not yet’, which is followed by the negated verb in the participle form -ra.”
Example:
ünege eme-re
not.yet come-PRS.PTCP
‘He has not come yet.’

Feature: Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Detailed comment: “Prohibition is expressed by the (irregular) imperative form of the negative verb”
Example:
tari beje e-se: nini-re
that man NEG-PST go-PRS
‘He didn’t go’.
bi: emün na:n e-si-m sa:-ra 1SG one yet NEG-PRS.PTCP-1SG know-PRS.PTCP
‘I don’t understand anything.’
e-ʤi soŋo-ro
NEG-IMP.2SG cry-PRS.PTCP
‘Don’t cry.’

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Detailed comment:
Verbal: e- ‘do not’
nominal: öntö ‘different, not’, a:sin ‘no’
Example:
tari beje e-se: nini-re 
that man NEG-PST go-PRS
‘He didn’t go’.
eri min-i: morin öntö
this 1SG-GEN horse NEG
‘This is not my horse.’
eri üxür-nin i:ge-ye a:sin 
this ox-3 horn-INAC NEG ‘This ox has no horns.’

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Detailed comment: “Passive and causative sentences are expressed morphologically by adding a suffix to a verb-stem respectively […]. As a rule, the agent in passive sentence takes the dative case […].
Example:
bi: e-dü munda-wu-su:
1SG this-DAT hit-PASS-PST.1SG
‘I was hit by him.’

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Is there clause chaining?
Example:
bi: uxxe-dü i:-ʤixe:-weje, batu min-ewe tan-sa:
1SG door-DAT enter-SUC-1SG Batu 1SG-ACC notice-PST
‘As soon as I entered the door, Batu noticed me.’

Feature: Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Detailed comment:
simultaneous: -mi
successive: -jixi, -jixa: (preceding action by a different doer)
perfective: -ta:n (perfect preceding action by the same doer)
etc.

Feature: Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Example:
eme-xe:n- ‘to make someone come’
aba min-ewe teggen-e xö:l-xeen-see
father 1SG-ACC cart-INAC put-CAUS-PST
‘Father made me put the cart (to a horse).’

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Are verbs reduplicated?
Are nouns reduplicated?
Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Comment: repeated adjectives most probably do not constitute phonological words

Feature: Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Example:
aja xonin ‘good sheep’
aja xonin-sal (PL)
aja xonin-ba (ACC)
aja xonin-bi (1SG)

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively
Example:
aja xonin-sal
good sheep-PL
‘good sheep’

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Detailed comment: There isn’t any kind of agreement between the numeral and the noun.
Example:
ilan üte 
three son
‘three sons’

Feature: What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Comment: "The head noun of noun phrases is always preceded by any kind of modifier.”

Feature: Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Example:
min-dü jü:r exin bi-si-n
1SG.OBL-DAT two elder.sister be-PRS.PTCP-3SG
‘I have two elder sisters.'

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Example:
eri üxür-nin i:ge-je a:sin 
this ox-3 horn-INAC NEG
‘This ox has no horns.’

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Example:
tari ilan üte-si
3SG three son-POSS
‘He has three sons.’

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Example:
eri üxür aja-ga:
this ox good-Q
‘Is this ox good?’
eri bitig sin-i:-ga:
this book 2SG-GEN-Q
‘Is this book yours?’

Feature: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Comment: “The compared object takes the ablative case”
Example:
üxür-ni: üldü-nin xonin-i: üldü-düxi antasi
cattle-GEN meat-3SG sheep-GEN meat-ABL delicious
‘Beef is more delicious than mutton.’

Feature: Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Example:
üxür-ni: üldü-nin xonin-i: üldü-düxi antasi
cattle-GEN meat-3SG sheep-GEN meat-ABL delicious
‘Beef is more delicious than mutton.’

Feature: Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Example:
üxür-ni: üldü-nin xonin-i: üldü-düxi antasi
cattle-GEN meat-3SG sheep-GEN meat-ABL delicious
‘Beef is more delicious than mutton.’

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Example:
tari beje e-se: nini-re
that man NEG-PST go-PRS ‘He didn’t go’.
bi: emün na:n e-si-m sa:-ra
1SG one yet NEG-PRS-1SG know-PRS.PTCP
‘I don’t understand anything.’

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Comment: it is not clear, whether the word can mark standard negation
Detailed comment: “There is a negative adverb unege ‘not yet’, which is followed by the negated verb in the participle form -ra.”
Example:
ünege eme-re
not.yet come-PRS.PTCP
‘He has not come yet.’

Feature: Does the verb for 'give' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there an inclusory construction?
Is there a phonologically free passive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ('particle' or 'auxiliary')?
Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Example:
bi: e-dü munda-wu-suu 1SG this-DAT hit-PASS-PST.1SG
‘I was hit by him.’

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?
Example: me:ni ‘oneself’

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Comment: The verb bi- ‘to be’ can be used to denote remote past.
Example:
üli-ce: bi-se:
go-PST be-PST
‘He has already gone.’

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Example:
jeb-mü:n-
eat-OPT-
‘to want to eat’

Feature: Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Example:
sin-i: a:wun-si
2SG-GEN hat-2SG
‘your hat’
min-i: jaxa
1SG-GEN baggage
‘my baggage’
min-i: bitig
1SG-GEN book
‘my book’

Feature: Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Comment: “The independent noun ulur (or olor?) ‘people,fellows’ is sometimes employed to express plurality of human nouns”.
Example: sawi ulur ‘students’.

Feature: Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Comment: There are two different forms, but it is not clear, what their distribution is.

Feature: Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Example:
si: i:le: tegeʤi-ndi
you where live-PRS.2SG
‘Where do you live?’
be:ʤin ʤakka o:xi goro bi-si-n
Beijing up.to how far be-PRS-3SG
‘How far is it to Beijing?’

Feature: Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Example:
ti:nüg eme-se: beje yesterday come-PST man
‘the man who came yesterday’
su:/sun-i: wa:-ra xonin 2SG.NOM/2SG-GEN kill-PRS sheep
‘the sheep you kill’
nantun-du nini-r teggü Nantun-DAT go-PRS road ‘the way to Nantun’
tarigan xadi-r erin
field reap-PRS time
‘the time when one reaps a field’

Feature: Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Are there correlative relative clauses?
Are there adjoined relative clauses?
Is there a decimal numeral system?
Example: 20 orin, 30 gotin, 40 dexi, 50 toNNEE,60 niNüNNEE, 70 nadaNNEE, 80 ʤaxuNNEE, 90 jereen

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Example: 1 emün, 2 ʤüür, 3 ilan, 4 digin, 5 toNa, 6 niNün, 7 nadan, 8 ʤaxun, 9 jegin, 10 ʤa:n

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Example: 20 orin, 40 dexi, 60 niŋüŋŋEE, 80 ʤaxuŋŋEE

Feature: Is there a body-part tallying system?
Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Example:
kino: isi-mi güŋken ʤo:nʤi-mi
movie see-PRS.PTCP.1S saying think-PRS.PTCP.1S
‘I think that I will watch a movie.’

Feature: Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Example:
kino: isi-mi güŋken ʤo:nʤi-mi
movie see-PRS.PTCP.1S saying think-PRS.PTCP.1S
‘I think that I will watch a movie.’

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Example:
xonin-i: nanda-wa:-ni
sheep-GEN skin-ACC-3SG
‘sheep skin (ACC)’

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Example:
xonin-i: nanda-wa:-ni
sheep-GEN skin-ACC-3SG
‘sheep skin (ACC)’

Feature: Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Is root structure predominantly polysyllabic?
Are complex tonal distinctions lacking?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there tongue root vowel harmony?
Is there an initial velar nasal?
Detailed comment: "Any consonants except N and r may appear in word-initial position.”

Feature: Is there an initial r-?
Detailed comment: "Any consonants except N and r may appear in word-initial position.”

Feature: Are there initial consonant clusters in native words?
Detailed comment: “any consonant cluster occurs neither word-initially nor finally”

Feature: Is there a voicing distinction in stops?
Detailed comment: "We recognize the following seventeen consonant phonemes in Solon:p t k b d g m n N c [tS] j [dZ] s x l r w y [j]”

Feature: Are borrowed verbs accommodated through a light-verb or a verbalizer?
Example: də:ŋxo munda- ‘to make a telephone call’ (lit. ‘to hit telephone’), daNga ta:n- ‘to smoke’ (lit. ‘to pull tobacco’)

Feature: Are property words verbally or nominally encoded?
Is there partial emphatic reduplication of nominal property words?
Example:
ab aja ‘very good’
xob xonnorin ‘coal-black’
nem nemikkün ‘very thin’

Feature: Are morphemes connected linearly in a way that there is a one on one relationship between a morpheme and its meaning?
Detailed comment: "Morphological process in Solon is basically suffix-agglutinative”.
Example:
xaxra:-sül-ni:-s
chicken-PL-GEN-2SG
‘of your chickens’
(Poppe 1931:117)

Feature: Is inflectional morphology predominantly suffixing?
Detailed comment: "Morphological process in Solon is basically suffix-agglutinative”.
Example:
xaxra:-sül-ni:-s
chicken-PL-GEN-2SG
‘of your chickens’
(Poppe 1931:117)

Feature: Is there a mi-ti opposition in 1 vs. 2 SG personal pronouns?
Is the secondary oblique stem of personal pronouns formed with a dental nasal?
Are gerunds or adverbial participles used to mark adverbial subordination?
Detailed comment:
coordinative converb -mi: simultaneous action by the same doer(s)
subordinative converb -kci ~ -cci: preceding action by the same doer(s)
perfective converb -ta:n(i): perfect preceding action by the same doer(s)
durative converb -gi:: continued or repeated action by the same doer(s)
conditional converb -kki: imperfect conditional action by a different doer(s)
successive converb -jixi, -jixa:: preceding action by a different doer(s)
Example:
tari arxi imi-gi: imi-gi: sotto-so:
3SG liquor drink-DUR drink-DUR get.drunk-PST
’He drank and drank and got drunk.’
